title: Sabre
text:
A sabre (<a href="French%20language">French</a>: ], sometimes spelt saber in <a href="American%20English">American English</a>) is a type of <a href="backsword">backsword</a> with a curved blade associated with the <a href="light%20cavalry">light cavalry</a> of the <a href="Early%20Modern%20warfare">early modern</a> and <a href="Napoleonic%20period">Napoleonic</a> periods. Originally associated with Central European cavalry such as the <a href="hussars">hussars</a>, the sabre became widespread in Western Europe during the <a href="Thirty%20Years%27%20War">Thirty Years' War</a>. Lighter sabres also became popular with infantry of the early 17th century. In the 19th century, models with less curving blades became common and were also used by <a href="heavy%20cavalry">heavy cavalry</a>.
The military sabre was used as a <a href="duel">duel</a>ling weapon in <a href="academic%20fencing">academic fencing</a> in the 19th century, giving rise to a discipline of modern <a href="Sabre%20%28fencing%29">sabre fencing</a> (introduced in the <a href="Fencing%20at%20the%201896%20Summer%20Olympics">1896 Summer Olympics</a>) loosely based on the characteristics of the historical weapon in that it allows for cuts as well as thrusts.
Etymology.
The English "sabre" is recorded from the 1670s, as a direct loan from French, where the "sabre" is an alteration of "sable", which was in turn loaned from German "Säbel", "Sabel" in the 1630s. The German word is on record from the 15th century, loaned from Polish "szabla", which was itself adopted from Hungarian "szabla" (14th century, later "szablya").
The spread of the Hungarian word to neighboring European languages took place in the context of the <a href="Ottoman%20wars%20in%20Europe">Ottoman wars in Europe</a> of the 15th to 17th centuries. The spelling "saber" became common in <a href="Comparison%20of%20American%20and%20British%20English">American English</a> in the second half of the 19th century.
The origin of the Hungarian word is unclear. It may itself be a loan from South Slavic (<a href="Serbo-Croatian">Serbo-Croatian</a> "<a href="%3Awikt%3A%D1%81%D0%B0%D0%B1%D1%99%D0%B0">сабља</a>", Common Slavic "<a href="%3Awikt%3AReconstruction%3AProto-Slavic/sablja">*sablja</a>"), which would ultimately derives from a <a href="Turkic%20languages">Turkic</a> source. In a more recent suggestion, the Hungarian word may ultimately derive from a <a href="Tungusic%20languages">Tungusic</a> source, via <a href="Kipchak%20languages">Kipchak Turkic</a> "selebe", with later metathesis (of "l-b" to "b-l") and apocope changed to "*seble", which would have changed its vocalisation in Hungarian to the recorded "sabla" (perhaps under the influence of the Hungarian word "szab-" "to crop; cut (into shape)".
History.
Origins.
Though <a href="backsword">single-edged cutting swords</a> already existed in the Ancient world, such as the ancient Egyptian and Sumerian <a href="sickle%20sword">sickle sword</a>s, these (usually forward instead of backward curving) weapons were chopping weapons for foot soldiers. This type of weapon developed into such heavy chopping weapons as the Greek <a href="Machaira">Machaira</a> and Anatolian Drepanon, and it still survives as the heavy <a href="Kukri">Kukri</a> chopping knife of the <a href="Gurkhas">Gurkhas</a>. However, in ancient China foot soldiers and cavalry often used a straight, single edged sword, and in the sixth century CE a longer, slightly curved cavalry variety of this weapon appeared in southern Siberia. This "proto-sabre" (the <a href="Turko-Mongol%20sabers">Turko-Mongol sabre</a>) had developed into the true cavalry sabre by the eight century CE, and by the ninth century, it had become the usual side arm on the Eurasian steppes. The sabre arrived in Europe with the <a href="Magyars">Magyars</a> and the <a href="Turkic%20expansion">Turkic expansion</a>. These oldest sabres had a slight curve, short, down-turned <a href="quillon">quillon</a>s, the grip facing the opposite direction to the blade and a sharp point with the top third of the reverse edge sharpened.
Early modern period.
The introduction of the sabre proper in Western Europe, along with the term "<a href="%3Awikt%3Asabre">sabre</a>" itself, dates to the 17th century, via the influence of the "<a href="szabla">szabla</a>" type ultimately derived from these medieval backswords. The adoption of the term is connected to the employment of Hungarian <a href="hussar">hussar</a> ("huszár") cavalry by Western European armies at the time. Hungarian hussars were employed as <a href="light%20cavalry">light cavalry</a>, with the role of harassing enemy <a href="skirmisher">skirmisher</a>s, overrunning artillery positions, and pursuing fleeing troops. In the late 17th and early 18th centuries, many Hungarian hussars fled to other Central and Western European countries and became the core of light cavalry formations created there. The Hungarian term "szablya" is ultimately traced to the <a href="Kipchak%20languages">northwestern Turkic</a> "selebe", with contamination from the Hungarian verb "szab" "to cut".
The original type of sabre, or Polish "szabla", was used as a <a href="cavalry">cavalry</a> weapon, possibly inspired by Hungarian or wider <a href="Turco-Mongol">Turco-Mongol</a> warfare.
The "<a href="karabela">karabela</a>" was a type of "szabla" popular in the late 17th century, worn by the <a href="Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian%20Commonwealth">Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth</a> nobility class, the "<a href="szlachta">szlachta</a>". While designed as a cavalry weapon, it also came to replace various types of straight-bladed swords used by infantry. The <a href="Swiss%20sabre">Swiss sabre</a> originated as a regular sword with a single-edged blade in the early 16th century, but by the 17th century began to exhibit specialized hilt types.
Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth.
In the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth (16th–18th century) a specific type of sabre-like <a href="melee%20weapon">melee weapon</a>, the "szabla", was used. Richly decorated sabres were popular among the <a href="Szlachta">Polish nobility</a>, who considered it to be one of the most important pieces of men's traditional attire. With time, the design of the sabre greatly evolved in the commonwealth and gave birth to a variety of sabre-like weapons, intended for many tasks. In the following centuries, the ideology of <a href="Sarmatism">Sarmatism</a> as well as the Polish fascination with <a href="Orient">Orient</a>al cultures, customs, cuisine and warfare resulted in the "szabla" becoming an indispensable part of traditional Polish culture.
Modern use.
The sabre saw extensive military use in the early 19th century, particularly in the <a href="Napoleonic%20Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a>, during which <a href="Napoleon%20I%20of%20France">Napoleon</a> used heavy <a href="cavalry">cavalry</a> charges to great effect against his enemies. Shorter versions of the sabre were also used as sidearms by dismounted units, although these were gradually replaced by <a href="fascine%20knives">fascine knives</a> and <a href="sword%20bayonets">sword bayonets</a> as the century went on. Although there was extensive debate over the effectiveness of weapons such as the sabre and <a href="lance">lance</a>, the sabre remained the standard weapon of cavalry for mounted action in most armies until <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a> and in a few armies until <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. Thereafter it was gradually relegated to the status of a <a href="ceremonial%20weapon">ceremonial weapon</a>, and most horse cavalry was replaced by <a href="armoured%20cavalry">armoured cavalry</a> from the 1930s onward.
Where horse mounted cavalry survived into World War II it was generally as mounted infantry without sabres. However the sabre was still carried by German cavalry until after the Polish campaign of 1939, after which this historic weapon was put into storage in 1941.
Romanian cavalry continued to carry their straight "thrusting" sabres on active service until at least 1941.
Napoleonic era.
Sabres were commonly used by the British in the Napoleonic era for light cavalry and infantry officers, as well as others. The elegant but effective 1803 pattern sword that the British Government authorized for use by infantry officers during the wars against <a href="Napoleon">Napoleon</a> featured a curved sabre blade which was often blued and engraved by the owner in accordance with his personal taste, and was based on the famously agile <a href="Pattern%201796%20light%20cavalry%20sabre">1796 light cavalry sabre</a> that was renowned for its brutal cutting power. Sabres were commonly used throughout this era by all armies, in much the same way that the British did.
The popularity of the sabre had rapidly increased in Britain throughout the 18th century for both infantry and cavalry use. This influence was predominately from southern and eastern Europe, with the Hungarians and Austrians listed as sources of influence for the sword and style of swordsmanship in British sources. The popularity of sabres had spread rapidly through Europe in the 16th and 17th centuries, and finally came to dominance as a military weapon in the British army in the 18th century, though straight blades remained in use by some, such as heavy cavalry units. (These were also replaced by sabres soon after the Napoleonic era).
The introduction of 'pattern' swords in the British army in 1788 led to a brief departure from the sabre in infantry use (though not for light cavalry), in favour of the lighter and straight bladed <a href="spadroon">spadroon</a>. The spadroon was universally unpopular, and many officers began to unofficially purchase and carry sabres once more. In 1799, the army accepted this under regulation for some units, and in 1803, produced a dedicated pattern of sabre for certain infantry officers (flank, rifle and staff officers). The 1803 pattern quickly saw much more widespread use than the regulation intended due to its effectiveness in combat, and fashionable appeal.
Pattern 1796 light cavalry sabre.
The most famous British sabre of the Napoleonic era is the 1796 light cavalry model, used by troopers and officers alike (officers versions can vary a little, but are much the same as the pattern troopers sword). It was in part designed by the famous <a href="John%20Le%20Marchant%20%28British%20Army%20officer%2C%20born%201766%29">John Le Marchant</a>, who worked to improve on the previous (1788) design based on his experience with the Austrians and Hungarians. Le Marchant also developed the first official British military sword exercise manual based on this experience, and his light cavalry sabre, and style of swordsmanship went on to heavily influence the training of the infantry and the navy.
The 1796 light cavalry sword was known for its brutal cutting power, easily severing limbs, and leading to the (unsubstantiated) myth that the French put in an official complaint to the British about its ferocity. This sword also saw widespread use with mounted artillery units, and the numerous militia units established in Britain to protect against a potential invasion by Napoleon.
Mameluke swords.
Though the sabre had already become very popular in Britain, experience in Egypt did lead to a fashion trend for <a href="mameluke%20sword">mameluke sword</a> style blades, a type of Middle Eastern <a href="scimitar">scimitar</a>, by some infantry and cavalry officers. These blades differ from the more typical British ones in that they have more extreme curvatures, in that they are usually not fullered, and in that they taper to a finer point. Mameluke swords also gained some popularity in France as well. <a href="Arthur%20Wellesley%2C%201st%20Duke%20of%20Wellington">Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington</a>, himself carried a mameluke-style sword. In 1831, the 'Mameluke' sword became the pattern sword for British generals, as well as officers of the United States Marine Corps; in this last capacity, it is still in such use at the present time.
United States.
The American victory over the rebellious forces in the citadel of <a href="Tripoli">Tripoli</a> in 1805, during the <a href="First%20Barbary%20War">First Barbary War</a>, led to the presentation of bejewelled examples of these swords to the senior officers of the <a href="United%20States%20Marine%20Corps">US Marines</a>. Officers of the US Marine Corps still use a mameluke-pattern dress sword. Although some genuine Turkish "<a href="kilij">kilij</a>" sabres were used by Westerners, most "mameluke sabres" were manufactured in Europe; although their hilts were very similar in form to the Ottoman prototype, their blades, even when an expanded "" was incorporated, tended to be longer, narrower and less curved than those of the true "kilij."
In the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">American Civil War</a>, the sabre was used infrequently as a weapon, but saw notable deployment in the <a href="Battle%20of%20Brandy%20Station">Battle of Brandy Station</a> and at East Cavalry Field at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Gettysburg">Battle of Gettysburg</a> in 1863. Many cavalrymen—particularly on the <a href="Confederate%20States%20Army">Confederate</a> side—eventually abandoned the long, heavy weapons in favour of <a href="revolver">revolver</a>s and <a href="carbine">carbine</a>s.
The last sabre issued to <a href="US%20cavalry">US cavalry</a> was the <a href="Model%201913%20Cavalry%20Saber">Patton saber</a> of 1913, designed to be mounted to the cavalryman's saddle. The Patton saber is only a saber on name. It is a straight, thrust-centric sword. A US War Department circular dated 18 April 1934 announced that the saber would no longer be issued to cavalry, and that it was to be completely discarded for use as a weapon. Only dress sabers, for use by officers only, and strictly as a badge of rank, were to be retained.
Police.
During the 19th and into the early 20th century, sabres were also used by both mounted and dismounted personnel in some European police forces. When the sabre was used by <a href="mounted%20police">mounted police</a> against crowds, the results could be devastating, as portrayed in a key scene in <a href="Doctor%20Zhivago%20%281965%20film%29">"Doctor Zhivago"</a>. The sabre was later phased out in favour of the <a href="Club%20%28weapon%29">baton</a>, or nightstick, for both practical and humanitarian reasons. The <a href="Gendarmerie%20%28Belgium%29">Gendarmerie</a> of Belgium used them until at least 1950, and the Swedish police forces until 1965.
Contemporary dress uniform.
Swords with sabre blades remain a component of the <a href="dress%20uniform">dress uniform</a>s worn by most national army, navy, air force, <a href="Marines">marine</a> and <a href="coast%20guard">coast guard</a> <a href="Military%20officer">officers</a>. Some militaries also issue ceremonial swords to their highest-ranking <a href="non-commissioned%20officer">non-commissioned officer</a>s; this is seen as an honour since, typically, non-commissioned, <a href="Enlisted%20rank">enlisted</a>/<a href="other%20ranks%20%28UK%29">other-rank</a> military service members are instead issued a <a href="cutlass">cutlass</a> blade rather than a sabre. Swords in the modern military are no longer used as weapons, and serve only ornamental or ceremonial functions. One distinctive modern use of sabres is in the <a href="sabre%20arch">sabre arch</a>, performed for servicemen or women getting married.
Modern sport fencing.
The <a href="Sabre%20%28fencing%29">modern fencing sabre</a> bears little resemblance to the cavalry sabre, having a thin, long straight blade. Rather, it is based upon the Italian dueling saber of classical fencing. One of the three weapons used in the sport of <a href="fencing">fencing</a>, it is a very fast-paced weapon with bouts characterized by quick footwork and cutting with the edge. The valid target area is from the waist up excluding the hands.
The concept of attacking above the waist only is a 20th-century change to the sport; previously sabreurs used to pad their legs against cutting slashes from their opponents. The reason for the above waist rule is unknown, as the sport of sabre fencing is based on the use of infantry sabres, not cavalry sabres.
In the last years, Saber fencing has been developing in <a href="Historical%20European%20Martial%20Arts">Historical European Martial Arts</a>, with blades that closely resemble the historical types, with techniques based on historical records.
